form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Mr. Moran (for himself and Mr. King) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs

form.official-title: To lift the trade embargo on Cuba, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Cuba Trade Act of 2015.

section.header: Removal of provisions restricting trade with Cuba

paragraph.text: Section 620(a) of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 (22 U.S.C. 2370(a)) is amended by striking (1) No assistance and all that follows through (2) Except and inserting Except.
Section 1709 of the Cuban Democracy Act of 1992 (22 U.S.C. 6008) is amended by striking section 620(a)(2) and inserting section 620(a).
The Cuban Democracy Act of 1992 (22 U.S.C. 6001 et seq.) is amended—
Paragraph (3) of section 204(b) of the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity (LIBERTAD) Act of 1996 (22 U.S.C. 6064(b)) is amended to read as follows:
section 1705(d) of the Cuban Democracy Act of 1992 (22 U.S.C. 6004(d));

subsection.header: Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act
subsection.text: The Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity (LIBERTAD) Act of 1996 (22 U.S.C. 6021 et seq.) is amended—

paragraph.text: in section 109(a) (22 U.S.C. 6039(a)), by striking (including section 102 of this Act).

subsection.header: Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000
subsection.text: The Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000 (22 U.S.C. 7201 et seq.) is amended—

paragraph.text: in section 906(a)(1) (22 U.S.C. 7205(a)(1)), by striking Cuba,;
by amending section 908 (22 U.S.C. 7207) to read as follows:

section.header: Prohibition on United States assistance and financing

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, no United States Government assistance, including United States foreign assistance, United States export assistance, and any United States credit or guarantees shall be available for commercial exports to Iran, Libya, North Korea, or Sudan.

subsection.header: Prohibition on foreign assistance and financing of trade with Cuba
subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the United States Government may not provide any foreign assistance to Cuba or any financial assistance, loans, loan guarantees, extension of credit, or other financing for exports to Cuba.

The President may waive the application of subsection (a) or (b) to the degree the President determines that it is in the national security interest of the United States to do so, or for humanitarian reasons.

section.header: Prohibition on use of taxpayer funds to promote trade with Cuba

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the Federal Government may not obligate or expend any funds to promote trade with or develop markets in Cuba.

subsection.header: Exclusion of certain Federal commodity promotion programs
subsection.text: Subsection (a) does not prohibit the obligation or expenditure of funds by Federal commodity promotion programs established in accordance with a commodity promotion law, as defined by section 501(a) of the Federal Agriculture Improvement and Reform Act of 1996 (7 U.S.C. 7401(a)).
